meta-review.comment:
Hippo Penny, folks! It's time to dive into the world of Hauntii, a game that'll make you question the meaning of life... or at least, what happens after we die.

As I embark on this eerie adventure, I'm reminded of those critics who think they're so smart. You know, the ones who say things like "considerable emotional impact" (The New York Times) and "welcome level of enjoyment" (Adventure Gamers). Yeah, they're basically saying that Hauntii is a game that'll tug at your heartstrings... or make you shrug it off.

But let's get to the gameplay, shall we? Hauntii is all about exploration and puzzle-solving. It's like being a tiny, faceless Druid (no offense, Moonloop Games!) searching for his lost love in the afterlife. The art style is monochromatic, which adds to the game's haunting atmosphere. I mean, who needs color when you can have moodiness?

Now, some critics might say that Hauntii is lacking in narrative and world-building (Hardcore Gamer, we're looking at you). But hey, sometimes a good puzzle or hidden pathway can make up for it, right? The level design is cleverly orchestrated, with light-and-dark contrast adding to the game's tension.

And then there are the possession-based mechanics. You know, those challenges and mini-games that'll keep you on your toes. It's like Hauntii is saying, "Hey, I may not be perfect, but at least I'm trying!"

Of course, no review would be complete without a nod to Rock, Paper, Shotgun. They're all about encouraging us to give this game a go. And honestly, that's what it needs â€“ a little bit of encouragement (and a few good puzzles) to make you keep playing.

So, if you're in the mood for an adventure that'll test your skills and challenge your emotions, Hauntii might be just the ticket. Just don't expect too much from the world-building or narrative... unless you count "the afterlife" as a plot twist (ba-dum-tss).

In conclusion, Hauntii is a game that's all about exploring the unknown and finding its way through the darkness. And who knows? You might just find your own lost love along the way.

That's it for this review, folks! Hippo Penny out!
